org.numenta.nupic.network

Class Network

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.numenta.nupic.network.Network
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, Persistable

    public class Network
extends java.lang.Object
implements Persistable

    A Network is the fundamental component of the HTM.java Network API. It is comprised of Regions which are in turn comprised of Layers; each Layer directly containing one or more algorithm or computational components such (i.e. Sensor, MultiEncoder, SpatialPooler, TemporalMemory, CLAClassifier etc.)

    Networks in HTM.java are extremely easy to compose. For instance, here is an example of a network which contains everything: 

     Parameters p = NetworkTestHarness.getParameters();
 p = p.union(NetworkTestHarness.getNetworkDemoTestEncoderParams());
 
 Network network = Network.create("test network", p)
     .add(Network.createRegion("r1")
         .add(Network.createLayer("1", p)
             .alterParameter(KEY.AUTO_CLASSIFY, Boolean.TRUE)
             .add(Anomaly.create())
             .add(new TemporalMemory())
             .add(new SpatialPooler())
             .add(Sensor.create(FileSensor::create, SensorParams.create(
                 Keys::path, "", ResourceLocator.path("rec-center-hourly.csv"))))));

    As you can see, Networks can be composed in "fluent" style making their declaration much more concise. While the above Network contains only 1 Region and only 1 Layer, Networks with many Regions and Layers within them; may be composed. For example: 

     Connections cons = new Connections();
 
 Network network = Network.create("test network", p)
     .add(Network.createRegion("r1")
         .add(Network.createLayer("1", p)
             .add(Anomaly.create())
             .add(new TemporalMemory())
             .add(new SpatialPooler())))
     .add(Network.createRegion("r2")
         .add(Network.createLayer("1", p)
             .using(cons)
             .alterParameter(KEY.AUTO_CLASSIFY, Boolean.TRUE)
             .add(new TemporalMemory()))                    
         .add(Network.createLayer("2", p)
             .using(cons)
             .add(new SpatialPooler())
             .add(Sensor.create(FileSensor::create, SensorParams.create(
                 Keys::path, "", ResourceLocator.path("rec-center-hourly.csv")))))
         .connect("1", "2")) // Tell the Region to connect the two layers Region.connect(String, String).
     .connect("r1", "r2");   // Tell the Network to connect the two regions connect(String, String).
    As you can see above, a Connections object is being shared among Region "r2"'s inner layers via the use of the Layer.using(Connections) method. Additionally, Parameters may be altered in place without changing the values in the original Parameters object, by calling Layer#alterParameter(KEY, Object) as seen in the above examples.

    Networks can be "observed", meaning they can return an Observable object which can be operated on in the map-reduce pattern of usage; and they can be subscribed to, to receive Inference objects as output from every process cycle. For instance: 

     network.observe().subscribe(new Subscriber<Inference>() {
      public void onCompleted() { System.out.println("Input Completed!"); }
      public void onError(Throwable e) { e.printStackTrace(); }
      public void onNext(Inference i) {
          System.out.println(String.format("%d: %s", i.getRecordNum(), Arrays.toString(i.getSDR())));
      }
 });

    Likewise, each Region within a Network may be "observed" and/or subscribed to; and each Layer may be observed and subscribed to as well - for those instances where you would like to obtain the processing from an individual component within the network for use outside the network in some other area of your application. To find and subscribe to individual components try: 

     Network network = ...
 
 Region region = network.lookup("<region name>");
 region.observe().subscribe(new Subscriber<Inference>() {
     public void onCompleted() { System.out.println("Input Completed!"); }
     public void onError(Throwable e) { e.printStackTrace(); }
     public void onNext(Inference i) {
         int[] sdr = i.getSDR();
         do something...
     }    
 }
 
 Layer l2_3 = region.lookup("<layer name>");
 l2_3.observe().subscribe(new Subscriber<Inference>() {
     public void onCompleted() { System.out.println("Input Completed!"); }
     public void onError(Throwable e) { e.printStackTrace(); }
     public void onNext(Inference i) {
         int[] sdr = i.getSDR();
         do something...
     }    
 }
    In addition there are many usage examples to be found in the org.numenta.nupic.examples.napi.hotgym package where there are tests which may be examined for details, and the NetworkAPIDemo
    Author:
    David Ray
    See Also:
    Region, Layer, Inference, ManualInput, NetworkAPIDemo, Serialized Form

      • getCheckPointOperator

        CheckPointOp<byte[]> getCheckPointOperator()
        USED INTERNALLY, DO NOT CALL Returns an rx.Observable operator that when subscribed to, invokes an operation that stores the state of this Network while keeping the Network up and running. The Network will be stored at the pre-configured location (in binary form only, not JSON).
        Returns:
        the CheckPointOp operator

      • restart

        public void restart()
        Restarts this Network. The network will run from the previous save point of the stored Network.
        See Also:
        #restart(boolean)} for a start at "saved-index" behavior explanation.

      • restart

        public void restart(boolean startAtIndex)
        Restarts this Network. If the "startAtIndex" flag is true, the Network will start from the last record number (plus 1) at which the Network was saved - continuing on from where it left off. The Network will achieve this by rebuilding the underlying Stream (if necessary, i.e. not for ObservableSensors) and skipping the number of records equal to the stored record number plus one, continuing from where it left off.
        Parameters:
        startAtIndex - flag indicating whether to start this Network from its previous save point.

      • setPublisher

        void setPublisher(Publisher p)

        DO NOT CALL THIS METHOD!

        Called internally by an ObservableSensor's factory method's creation of a new ObservableSensor. This would usually happen following a halt or deserialization.

        Parameters:
        p - the new Publisher created upon reconstitution of a new ObservableSensor

        public java.util.Iterator<Region> iterator()

      • compute

        public <T> void compute(T input)
        Used to manually input data into a Network, the other way being the call to start() for a Network that contains a Region that contains a Layer which in turn contains a Sensor -OR- subscribing a receiving Region to this Region's output Observable.
        Parameters:
        input - One of (int[], String[], ManualInput, or Map<String, Object>)

      • addDummySubscriber

        void addDummySubscriber()
        Added when a synchronous call is made and there is no subscriber. No Subscriber leads to the observable chain not being constructed, therefore we must always have at least one subscriber.
